The Gukanshō records that Kōgen ruled from the palace of Sakaihara-no-miya at Karu in what will come to be known as Yamato province.Brown, p. 252. ==Traditional history== Kōgen is almost certainly a legend. The Kojiki records only his name and genealogy. The Nihonshoki includes Kōgen as the seventh of .Aston, pp. 146-147. Kōgen was the eldest son of Emperor Kōrei. Some scholars question the existence of the first nine emperors. These critics consider Kōgen's grandson (Emperor Sujin) to be the earliest to have actually existed."Life in the Cloudy Imperial Fishbowl," Japan Times. March 27, 2007; retrieved 2011-10-19. ==Events of Kōgen's life== The absence of information about Kōgen does not imply that no such person ever existed. Very little information is available for study prior to the reign of the 29th monarch, Emperor Kimmei.Titsingh, pp. 34-36; Brown, pp. 261-262; Varley, pp. 123-124. The Abe clan are said to have descended from a son of Emperor Kōgen.Asakawa, Kan'ichi. (1903). The Early Institutional Life of Japan, p.140. === After his death === This emperor's official name after his death (his posthumous name) was regularized many centuries after the lifetime which was ascribed to Kōgen.Aston, pp. 147-148. The actual site of his grave is not known. According to the Imperial Household Agency, this emperor is venerated at a memorial Shinto shrine (misasagi) at Nara. ==Related pages== * Emperor of Japan * List of emperors of Japan * Japanese imperial family tree == References == Category:Emperors of Japan
